text.0: the altar hath been made for thee to rest on come like a panting courser and be seated.
text.1: loosen thy flying steeds set free thy horses who bear thee swiftly nigh at eve and morning.
text.2: these men have come to indra for assistance shall he not quickly come upon these pathways.
text.3: may the gods quell the fury of the dāsa and may they lead our folk to happy fortune.
text.4: he who hath only wish as his possession casts on himself casts foam amid the waters.
text.5: both wives of kuyava in milk have bathed them may they be drowned within the depth of Śiphā.
text.6: this hath his kinship checked who lives beside us with ancient streams forth speeds and rules the hero.
text.7: añjasī kuliśī and virapatnī delighting him bear milk upon their waters.
text.8: soon as this dasyus traces were discovered as she who knows her home he sought the dwelling.
text.9: now think thou of us maghavan nor cast us away as doth a profligate his treasure.
text.10: indra as such give us a share of sunlight of waters sinlessness and reputation.
text.11: do thou no harm to our yet unborn offspring our trust is in thy mighty indrapower.
text.12: now we i think in thee as such have trusted lead us on mighty one to ample riches.
text.13: in no unready house give us o indra invoked of many food and drink when hungry.
text.14: slay us not indra do not thou forsake us steal not away the joys which we delight in.
text.15: rend not our unborn brood strong lord of bounty our vessels with the life that is within them.
text.16: come to us they have called thee somalover here is the pressed juice drink thereof for rapture.
text.17: widelycapacious pour it down within thee and invocated hear us like a father.
